div1.p: Special Orders #51 orders Reed to Tampa, Florida and then back to Havana, Cuba on business pertaining to an investigation of electrozone as a disinfectant and germicide. Included is a handwritten note by Truby. [Courtesy of the National Archives and Records Administration]

SPECIAL ORDERS,
No. 51.

HEADQUARTERS OF THE ARMY,
ADJUTANT GENERAL'S OFFICE,
Washington, March 2, 1900.

1. By direction of the Secretary of War, a board of officers
to consist of--
Colonel Wallace F. Randolph, 1st U. S. Artillery;

Major James W. Pope, quartermaster, U. S. Army, and
Captain Henry W. Hubbell, 1st U. S. Artillery.
will convene at Sullivans Island, South Carolina, on March 6,
1900, or as soon thereafter as practicable, for the purpose of
ascertaining the prices at which the different holdings on the
two tracts of land on Sullivans Island, South Carolina, the
title to which was recently ceded by the legislature of that
State, can be obtained, and to recommend in each case whether
or not, in the opinion of the board, such holdings should be
purchased at the prices stated or whether or not it would be to
the advantage of the Government to institute condemnation
proceedings for their acquisition. To this end the Quarter-
master General of the Army is authorized to employ the nec-
essary expert assistance for the board in determining these
values, at a compensation not to exceed $500.
The junior member will act as recorder.

Upon the final adjournment of the board, Major Pope will
return to his proper station, the travel enjoined being neces-
sary for the public service.

2. By direction of the Secretary of War, the following trans-
fers are made, to take effect this date:

First Lieutenant Edwin O. Sarratt, from the 6th U. S. Artil-
lery to the 4th U. S. Artillery. Light Battery F;

First Lieutenant Lawrence S. Miller, from the 4th U. S. Ar-
tillery to the 6th U. S. Artillery, Battery O.

The officers named will proceed to join the batteries to which
they are transferred. The travel enjoined is necessary for the
public service.

3. Leave of absence for twenty days is granted Captain
Frederick S. Strong, 4th U. S. Artillery.

4. By direction of the Secretary of War, Captain Frederick
W. Sibley, 2d U. S. Cavalry, will proceed to San Antonio,
Texas, and report in person to the commanding officer, Depart-
ment of Texas, for duty as acting inspector general of that
department. The travel enjoined is necessary for the public
service.

the posts, and repair to their homes:

First Sergeant John Dunne, Battery C, 4th U. S. Artillery,
Fort Caswell, North Carolina;

Sergeant John Lewis, Troop A, 9th U. S. Cavalry, Fort
Grant, Arizona Territory.

The Quartermaster's Department will furnish the necessary
transportation. It being impracticable for these soldiers to
carry rations of any kind commutation therefor will be paid
in advance for the necessary number of days' travel. The
journeys are necessary for the public service.

12. By direction of the Assistant Secretary of War, Corporal
Palmer J. Hahn, Company M, 28th Infantry, U. S. Volunteers,
now at the recruiting station, Easton, Pennsylvania, will be
discharged without honor, by reason of desertion, from the
service of the United States by the officer in charge of that
station. This soldier is not entitled to travel-pay.

13. By direction of the Assistant Secretary of War, Private
John A. Kress, jr., Company M, 10th U. S. Infantry, Fort
Crook, Nebraska, is transferred as 2d class private to the Signal
Corps, U. S. Army. He will be sent to the Signal Corps Post,
Fort Myer, Virginia, and will report upon arrival to the com-
manding officer for duty.

14. By direction of the Assistant Secretary of War, the fol-
lowing named enlisted men, supposed to be at the stations desig-
nated after their respective names, will be discharged the serv-
ice of the United States, under paragraphs 145 and 146 of the
Regulations by the commanding officers of their respective sta-
tions:

Private Herman Haag, Battery G, 4th U. S. Artillery, Fort
Monroe, Virginia:

Principal Musician Carl A. Holmgoist, band, 15th U. S. In-
fantry, Plattsburg Barracks, New York.

15. By direction of the Secretary of War, Major Walter
Reed, surgeon, U. S. Army, will proceed from this city to
Tampa, Florida, on official business pertaining to the Medical
Department, under such instructions as may be communicated
to him by the Surgeon General of the Army, and on completion
of this duty will return to his station in this city. The travel
enjoined is necessary for the public service.

16. By direction of the Secretary of War, Major Walter Reed,
surgeon, U. S. Army, will proceed from Tampa, Florida, to
Havana, Cuba, on official business pertaining to an investiga-
4
tion as to the practical use of electrozone as a disinfectant and
germicide in Havana, and on completion of this duty will re-
turn to Tampa, Florida. Major Reed will transmit a report
of his investigations to the Surgeon General of the Army,
through headquarters, Military Division of Cuba. The travel
enjoined is necessary for the public service.

17. By direction of the Assistant Secretary of War, the fol-
lowing-named enlisted men, supposed to be at the stations
designated after their respective names, will be discharged the
service of the United States by the commanding officers of their
respective stations:

Sergeant David H. Bentz, Signal Corps, U. S. Army, San-
tiago, Cuba;

Private Frank W. Ernst, Troop H, 3d U. S. Cavalry, Fort
Myer, Virginia;

Private Frank J. Stands, Company M, 2d U. S. Infantry,
Pasa Caballos, Cuba;

Sergeant Alfred Stone, Company C, Puerto Rican Battalion,
San Juan, Puerto Rico.
These soldiers are not entitled to travel-pay.

18. By direction of the Secretary of War, Captain Robert L.
Brown, assistant quartermaster, U. S. Volunteers, is relieved
from further duty at Cincinnati, Ohio, and will proceed at once
to Chicago, Illinois, and report in person to the commanding
general, Department of the Lakes, for temporary duty as as-
sistant to the chief quartermaster of that department, to relieve
Captain Charles D. Palmer, assistant quartermaster, U. S.
Army. Captain Palmer upon being thus relieved will proceed
to San Francisco, California, and report in person to the com-
manding general, Department of California, for duty. The
travel enjoined is necessary for the public service.

19. By direction of the Secretary of War, Captain Charles D.
Palmer, assistant quartermaster, U. S. Army, upon the com-
pletion of the duty assigned him by the commanding general,
Department of California, will proceed by Government trans-
port from San Francisco, California, to Manila, Philippine
Islands, and report in person to the commanding general, De-
partment of the Pacific and 8th Army Corps, for assignment
to duty under his direction. The travel enjoined is necessary
for the public service.
BY COMMAND OF MAJOR GENERAL MILES:

THOMAS WARD,
Acting Adjutant General.
Hdqrs of the Army
